name: 2023 ISL G1
problem:
Let $ABCDE$ be a convex pentagon such that $\angle ABC = \angle AED = 90^\circ$. Suppose that the midpoint of $CD$ is the circumcenter of triangle $ABE$. Let $O$ be the circumcenter of triangle $ACD$.

Prove that line $AO$ passes through the midpoint of segment $BE$.
formal_statement: c = free c; d = free d; a = free a; f = midpoint f c d; b = on_circle b f a, on_dia b a c; e = on_circle e f a, on_dia e a d; o = circle o a c d; x = on_line x a o, on_line x b e ? cong x b x e

name: 2023 ISL G2
problem: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with $AC > BC,$ let $\omega$ be the circumcircle of $\triangle ABC,$ and let $r$ be its radius. Point $P$ is chosen on $\overline{AC},$ such taht $BC=CP,$ and point $S$ is the foot of the perpendicular from $P$ to $\overline{AB},$. Ray $BP$ mets $\omega$ again at $D$. Point $Q$ is chosen on line $SP$ such that $PQ = r$ and $S,P,Q$ lie on a line in that order. Finally, let $E$ be a point satisfying $\overline{AE}, \perp \overline{CQ},$ and $\overline{BE}, \perp \overline{DQ},$. Prove that $E$ lies on $\omega$.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; o = circle o a b c; p = on_line p a c, eqdistance p c b c; s = foot s p a b; d = on_circum d a b c, on_line d b p; q = on_line q s p, eqdistance q p o a; e = on_tline e a c q, on_tline e b d q ? cyclic a b c e

name: 2023 ISL G3
problem:
Let $ABCD$ be a cyclic quadrilateral with $\angle BAD < \angle ADC$. Let $M$ be the midpoint of the arc $CD$ not containing $A$. Suppose there is a point $P$ inside $ABCD$ such that $\angle ADB = \angle CPD$ and $\angle ADP = \angle PCB$. 

Prove that lines $AD, PM$, and $BC$ are concurrent.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; d = on_circum d a b c; m = on_circum m a b c, on_bline m c d; p = free p; x = on_line x a d, on_line x b c ? coll x p m

name: 2023 ISL G4
problem: Let $ABC$ be an acute-angled triangle with $AB < AC$. Let $\Omega$ be the circumcircle of $ABC$. Let $S$ be the midpoint of the arc $CB$ of $\Omega$ containing $A$. The perpendicular from $A$ to $BC$ meets $BS$ at $D$ and meets $\Omega$ again at $E \neq A$. The line through $D$ parallel to $BC$ meets line $BE$ at $L$. Denote the circumcircle of triangle $BDL$ by $\omega$. Let $\omega$ meet $\Omega$ again at $P \neq B$. Prove that the line tangent to $\omega$ at $P$ meets line $BS$ on the internal angle bisector of $\angle BAC$.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; s = on_circum s a b c, on_bline s b c; d = on_line d b s, on_tline d a b c; e = on_circum e a b c, on_tline e a b c; l = on_line l b e, on_pline l d b c; w = circle w b d l; p = on_circum p b d l, on_circum p a b c; z = on_line z b s, on_tline z p p w ? eqangle b a a z z a a c

name: 2023 ISL G5
problem:
Let $ABC$ be an acute-angled triangle with circumcircle $\omega$ and circumcentre $O$. Points $D\neq B$ and $E\neq C$ lie on $\omega$ such that $BD\perp AC$ and $CE\perp AB$. Let $CO$ meet $AB$ at $X$, and $BO$ meet $AC$ at $Y$.

Prove that the circumcircles of triangles $BXD$ and $CYE$ have an intersection lie on line $AO$.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; o = circle o a b c; d = on_tline d b a c, on_circum d a b c; e = on_tline e c a b, on_circum e a b c; x = on_line x c o, on_line x a b; y = on_line y b o, on_line y a c; t = on_circum t b x d, on_circum t c y e ? coll a o t

name: 2023 ISL G6
problem:
Let $ABC$ be an acute-angled triangle with circumcircle $\omega$. A circle $\Gamma$ is internally tangent to $\omega$ at $A$ and also tangent to $BC$ at $D$. Let $AB$ and $AC$ intersect $\Gamma$ at $P$ and $Q$ respectively. Let $M$ and $N$ be points on line $BC$ such that $B$ is the midpoint of $DM$ and $C$ is the midpoint of $DN$. Lines $MP$ and $NQ$ meet at $K$ and intersect $\Gamma$ again at $I$ and $J$ respectively. The ray $KA$ meets the circumcircle of triangle $IJK$ again at $X\neq K$.

Prove that $\angle BXP = \angle CXQ$.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; d = on_line d b c; p = on_line p a b; q = on_line q a c; m = mirror m d b; n = mirror n d c; k = on_line k m p, on_line k n q; i = on_line i m p; j = on_line j n q; x = on_line x k a, on_circum x i j k ? eqangle b x x p c x x q

name: 2023 ISL G7
problem:
Let $ABC$ be an acute, scalene triangle with orthocentre $H$. Let $\ell_a$ be the line through the reflection of $B$ with respect to $CH$ and the reflection of $C$ with respect to $BH$. Lines $\ell_b$ and $\ell_c$ are defined similarly. Suppose lines $\ell_a$, $\ell_b$, and $\ell_c$ determine a triangle $\mathcal T$.

Prove that the orthocentre of $\mathcal T$, the circumcentre of $\mathcal T$, and $H$ are collinear.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; h = orthocenter h a b c; bA = reflect bA b c h; cA = reflect cA c b h; aB = reflect aB a c h; cB = reflect cB c a h; aC = reflect aC a b h; bC = reflect bC b a h; p = on_line p bA cA, on_line p aB cB; q = on_line q aB cB, on_line q aC bC; r = on_line r aC bC, on_line r bA cA; hT = orthocenter hT p q r; oT = circle oT p q r ? coll hT oT h

name: 2023 ISL G8
problem:
Let $ABC$ be an equilateral triangle. Let $A_1,B_1,C_1$ be interior points of $ABC$ such that $BA_1=A_1C$, $CB_1=B_1A$, $AC_1=C_1B$, and
$$\angle BA_1C+\angle CB_1A+\angle AC_1B=480^\circ$$
Let $BC_1$ and $CB_1$ meet at $A_2,$ let $CA_1$ and $AC_1$ meet at $B_2,$ and let $AB_1$ and $BA_1$ meet at $C_2.$
Prove that if triangle $A_1B_1C_1$ is scalene, then the three circumcircles of triangles $AA_1A_2, BB_1B_2$
and $CC_1C_2$ all pass through two common points.

(Note: a scalene triangle is one where no two sides have equal length.)
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; a1 = on_bline a1 b c; b1 = on_bline b1 c a; c1 = on_bline c1 a b; a2 = on_line a2 b c1, on_line a2 c b1; b2 = on_line b2 c a1, on_line b2 a c1; c2 = on_line c2 a b1, on_line c2 b a1; x = on_circum x a a1 a2, on_circum x b b1 b2 ? cyclic x c c1 c2

name: 2022 IMO Shortlist G1
problem: Let $ABCDE$ be a convex pentagon such that $BC=DE$. Assume that there is a point $T$ inside $ABCDE$ with $TB=TD,TC=TE$ and $\angle ABT = \angle TEA$. Let line $AB$ intersect lines $CD$ and $CT$ at points $P$ and $Q$, respectively. Assume that the points $P,B,A,Q$ occur on their line in that order. Let line $AE$ intersect $CD$ and $DT$ at points $R$ and $S$, respectively. Assume that the points $R,E,A,S$ occur on their line in that order. Prove that the points $P,S,Q,R$ lie on a circle.
formal_statement: a = free a; b = free b; t = free t; e = eqangle3 e a t b t a; c = on_circle c t e; d = on_circle d t b, eqdistance d e b c; p = on_line p a b, on_line p c d; q = on_line q a b, on_line q c t; r = on_line r a e, on_line r c d; s = on_line s a e, on_line s d t ? cyclic p s q r

name: 2022 IMO Shortlist G2
problem:
In the acute-angled triangle $ABC$, the point $F$ is the foot of the altitude from $A$, and $P$ is a point on the segment $AF$. The lines through $P$ parallel to $AC$ and $AB$ meet $BC$ at $D$ and $E$, respectively. Points $X \ne A$ and $Y \ne A$ lie on the circles $ABD$ and $ACE$, respectively, such that $DA = DX$ and $EA = EY$. 
Prove that $B, C, X,$ and $Y$ are concyclic.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; f = foot f a b c; p = on_line p a f; d = on_line d b c, on_pline d p a c; e = on_line e b c, on_pline e p a b; x = on_circum x a b d, eqdistance x d d a; y = on_circum y a c e, eqdistance y e e a ? cyclic b c x y

name: 2022 IMO Shortlist G3
problem: Let $ABCD$ be a cyclic quadrilateral. Assume that the points $Q, A, B, P$ are collinear in this order, in such a way that the line $AC$ is tangent to the circle $ADQ$, and the line $BD$ is tangent to the circle $BCP$. Let $M$ and $N$ be the midpoints of segments $BC$ and $AD$, respectively. Prove that the following three lines are concurrent: line $CD$, the tangent of circle $ANQ$ at point $A$, and the tangent to circle $BMP$ at point $B$.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; d = on_circum d a b c; o1 = on_tline o1 a a c, on_bline o1 a d; q = on_line q a b, on_circle q o1 a; o2 = on_tline o2 b b d, on_bline o2 b c; p = on_line p a b, on_circle p o2 b; m = midpoint m b c; n = midpoint n a d; o3 = circle o3 a n q; x = on_line x c d, on_tline x a a o3; o4 = circle o4 b m p ? perp x b b o4

name: 2022 IMO Shortlist G4
problem:
Let $ABC$ be an acute-angled triangle with $AC > AB$, let $O$ be its circumcentre, and let $D$ be a point on the segment $BC$. The line through $D$ perpendicular to $BC$ intersects the lines $AO, AC,$ and $AB$ at $W, X,$ and $Y,$ respectively. The circumcircles of triangles $AXY$ and $ABC$ intersect again at $Z \ne A$. 
Prove that if $W \ne D$ and $OW = OD,$ then $DZ$ is tangent to the circle $AXY.$
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; o = circle o a b c; d = on_line d b c; w = on_line w a o, on_tline w d b c; x = on_line x a c, on_tline x d b c; y = on_line y a b, on_tline y d b c; z = on_circum z a x y, on_circum z a b c ? eqangle d z z x a y y x

name: 2022 IMO Shortlist G5
problem: Let $ABC$ be a triangle and $\ell_1,\ell_2$ be two parallel lines. Let $\ell_i$ intersects line $BC,CA,AB$ at $X_i,Y_i,Z_i$, respectively. Let $\Delta_i$ be the triangle formed by the line passed through $X_i$ and perpendicular to $BC$, the line passed through $Y_i$ and perpendicular to $CA$, and the line passed through $Z_i$ and perpendicular to $AB$. Prove that the circumcircles of $\Delta_1$ and $\Delta_2$ are tangent.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; x1 = on_line x1 b c; y1 = on_line y1 c a; z1 = on_line z1 a b; x2 = on_line x2 b c; y2 = on_line y2 c a; z2 = on_line z2 a b; A1 = on_tline A1 x1 b c, on_tline A1 y1 c a; B1 = on_tline B1 y1 c a, on_tline B1 z1 a b; C1 = on_tline C1 z1 a b, on_tline C1 x1 b c; A2 = on_tline A2 x2 b c, on_tline A2 y2 c a; B2 = on_tline B2 y2 c a, on_tline B2 z2 a b; C2 = on_tline C2 z2 a b, on_tline C2 x2 b c ? eqangle A1 B1 B1 C1 A2 B2 B2 C2

name: 2022 IMO Shortlist G6
problem: Let $ABC$ be an acute triangle with altitude $\overline{AH},$, and let $P$ be a variable point such that the angle bisectors $k$ and $\ell$ of $\angle PBC$ and $\angle PCB$, respectively, meet on $\overline{AH},$. Let $k$ meet $\overline{AC},$ at $E$, $\ell$ meet $\overline{AB},$ at $F$, and $\overline{EF},$ meet $\overline{AH},$ at $Q$. Prove that as $P$ varies, line $PQ$ passes through a fixed point.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; h = foot h a b c; p = free p; e = angle_bisector e p b c, on_line e a c; f = angle_bisector f p c b, on_line f a b; q = on_line q e f, on_line q a h; x = free x ? coll p q x

name: 2022 IMO Shortlist G7
problem: Two triangles $ABC, A’B’C’$ have the same orthocenter $H$ and the same circumcircle with center $O$.  Letting $PQR$ be the triangle formed by $AA’, BB’, CC’$, prove that the circumcenter of $PQR$ lies on $OH$.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; a' b' c' = triangle a' b' c'; h = orthocenter h a b c; o = circle o a b c, circle o a' b' c'; p = on_line p b b', on_line p c c'; q = on_line q c c', on_line q a a'; r = on_line r a a', on_line r b b'; x = circle x p q r ? coll x o h

name: 2022 IMO Shortlist G8
problem:
Let $AA'BCC'B'$ be a convex cyclic hexagon such that $AC$ is tangent to the incircle of the triangle $A'B'C'$, and $A'C'$ is tangent to the incircle of the triangle $ABC$. Let the lines $AB$ and $A'B'$ meet at $X$ and let the lines $BC$ and $B'C'$ meet at $Y$.

Prove that if $XBYB'$ is a convex quadrilateral, then it has an incircle.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; a' = on_circum a' a b c; b' = on_circum b' a b c; c' = on_circum c' a b c; x = on_line x a b, on_line x a' b'; y = on_line y b c, on_line y b' c' ? eqratio x b y b' b y x b'

name: 2021 IMO Shortlist G1
problem: Let $ABCD$ be a parallelogram with $AC=BC.$ A point $P$ is chosen on the extension of ray $AB$ past $B.$ The circumcircle of $ACD$ meets the segment $PD$ again at $Q.$ The circumcircle of triangle $APQ$ meets the segment $PC$ at $R.$ Prove that lines $CD,AQ,BR$ are concurrent.
formal_statement: a = free a; b = free b; c = on_bline c a b; d = on_pline d c a b, on_pline d a b c; p = on_line p a b; q = on_circum q a c d, on_line q p d; r = on_circum r a p q, on_line r p c; x = on_line x c d, on_line x a q ? coll b r x

name: 2021 IMO Shortlist G2
problem: Let $\Gamma$ be a circle with centre $I$, and $A B C D$ a convex quadrilateral such that each of the segments $A B, B C, C D$ and $D A$ is tangent to $\Gamma$. Let $\Omega$ be the circumcircle of the triangle $A I C$. The extension of $B A$ beyond $A$ meets $\Omega$ at $X$, and the extension of $B C$ beyond $C$ meets $\Omega$ at $Z$. The extensions of $A D$ and $C D$ beyond $D$ meet $\Omega$ at $Y$ and $T$, respectively. Prove that \[A D+D T+T X+X A=C D+D Y+Y Z+Z C.\]
formal_statement: i = free i; a = free a; b = free b; c = free c; d = free d; o = circle o a i c; x = on_line x b a, on_circle x o a; z = on_line z b c, on_circle z o a; y = on_line y a d, on_circle y o a; t = on_line t c d, on_circle t o a ? eqratio a d d t t x x a c d d y y z z c

name: 2021 IMO Shortlist G3
problem: Consider a $100\times 100$ square unit lattice $\textbf{L},$ (hence $\textbf{L},$ has $10000$ points). Suppose $\mathcal{F},$ is a set of polygons such that all vertices of polygons in $\mathcal{F},$ lie in $\textbf{L},$ and every point in $\textbf{L},$ is the vertex of exactly one polygon in $\mathcal{F},.$ Find the maximum possible sum of the areas of the polygons in $\mathcal{F},.$
formal_statement: p = free p ? eqangle p p p p p p p p

name: 2021 IMO Shortlist G4
problem: uc
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; om = circle om a b c; d = on_circle d om a; e = on_line e b a, on_tline e d d om; f = on_line f b c, on_tline f d d om; t = on_pline t e c d, on_pline t f a d; k = on_line k d f, on_circle k t d; x = on_line x a c, on_line x d t ? coll x b k

name: 2021 IMO Shortlist G5
problem:
Let $ABCD$ be a cyclic quadrilateral whose sides have pairwise different lengths. Let $O$ be the circumcenter of $ABCD$. The internal angle bisectors of $\angle ABC$ and $\angle ADC$ meet $AC$ at $B_1$ and $D_1$, respectively. Let $O_B$ be the center of the circle which passes through $B$ and is tangent to $\overline{AC},$ at $D_1$. Similarly, let $O_D$ be the center of the circle which passes through $D$ and is tangent to $\overline{AC},$ at $B_1$.

Assume that $\overline{BD_1}, \parallel \overline{DB_1},$. Prove that $O$ lies on the line $\overline{O_BO_D},$.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; o = circle o a b c; d = on_circum d a b c; b1 = angle_bisector b1 a b c, on_line b1 a c; d1 = angle_bisector d1 a d c, on_line d1 a c; ob = free ob; od = free od ? coll ob od o

name: 2021 IMO Shortlist G6
problem: Find all integers $n\geq 3$ for which every convex equilateral $n$-gon of side length $1$ contains an equilateral triangle of side length $1$. (Here, polygons contain their boundaries.)
formal_statement: a = free a; b = free b; c = free c ? eqratio a b b c a b b c

name: 2021 IMO Shortlist G7
problem: Let $D$ be an interior point of the acute triangle $ABC$ with $AB > AC$ so that $\angle DAB = \angle CAD.$ The point $E$ on the segment $AC$ satisfies $\angle ADE =\angle BCD,$ the point $F$ on the segment $AB$ satisfies $\angle FDA =\angle DBC,$ and the point $X$ on the line $AC$ satisfies $CX = BX.$ Let $O_1$ and $O_2$ be the circumcenters of the triangles $ADC$ and $EXD,$ respectively. Prove that the lines $BC, EF,$ and $O_1O_2$ are concurrent.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; d = angle_bisector d b a c; e = on_line e a c, on_aline e d a d c b; f = on_line f a b, on_aline f d a d b c; x = on_line x a c, on_bline x b c; o1 = circle o1 a d c; o2 = circle o2 e x d; p = on_line p b c, on_line p e f ? coll p o1 o2

name: 2021 IMO Shortlist G8
problem: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with circumcircle $\omega$ and let $\Omega_A$ be the $A$-excircle. Let $X$ and $Y$ be the intersection points of $\omega$ and $\Omega_A$. Let $P$ and $Q$ be the projections of $A$ onto the tangent lines to $\Omega_A$ at $X$ and $Y$ respectively. The tangent line at $P$ to the circumcircle of the triangle $APX$ intersects the tangent line at $Q$ to the circumcircle of the triangle $AQY$ at a point $R$. Prove that $\overline{AR}, \perp \overline{BC},$.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; e = excenter e a b c; f = foot f e a b; x = on_circum x a b c, on_circle x e f; y = on_circum y a b c, on_circle y e f; p = on_dia p a x, on_tline p x x e; q = on_dia q a y, on_tline q y y e; o1 = circle o1 a p x; o2 = circle o2 a q y; r = on_tline r p p o1, on_tline r q q o2 ? perp a r b c

name: 2020 IMO Shortlist G1
problem:
Let $ABC$ be an isosceles triangle with $BC=CA$, and let $D$ be a point inside side $AB$ such that $AD< DB$. Let $P$ and $Q$ be two points inside sides $BC$ and $CA$, respectively, such that $\angle DPB = \angle DQA = 90^{\circ},$. Let the perpendicular bisector of $PQ$ meet line segment $CQ$ at $E$, and let the circumcircles of triangles $ABC$ and $CPQ$ meet again at point $F$, different from $C$.
Suppose that $P$, $E$, $F$ are collinear. Prove that $\angle ACB = 90^{\circ},$.
formal_statement: a b = segment a b; c = on_bline c a b; d = on_line d a b; p = on_line p b c, on_dia p d b; q = on_line q c a, on_dia q d a; e = on_line e c q, on_bline e p q; f = on_circum f a b c, on_circum f c p q ? perp a c b c

name: 2020 IMO Shortlist G2
problem:
Consider the convex quadrilateral $ABCD$. The point $P$ is in the interior of $ABCD$. The following ratio equalities hold:
\[\angle PAD:\angle PBA:\angle DPA=1:2:3=\angle CBP:\angle BAP:\angle BPC\]
Prove that the following three lines meet in a point: the internal bisectors of angles $\angle ADP$ and $\angle PCB$ and the perpendicular bisector of segment $AB$.
formal_statement: a = free a; b = free b; c = free c; d = free d; p = free p; x = angle_bisector x a d p, angle_bisector x p c b ? cong x a x b

name: 2020 IMO Shortlist G3
problem: Let $ABCD$ be a convex quadrilateral with $\angle ABC>90$, $CDA>90$ and $\angle DAB=\angle BCD$. Denote by $E$ and $F$ the reflections of $A$ in lines $BC$ and $CD$, respectively. Suppose that the segments $AE$ and $AF$ meet the line $BD$ at $K$ and $L$, respectively. Prove that the circumcircles of triangles $BEK$ and $DFL$ are tangent to each other.
formal_statement: d = free d; b = free b; c = free c; a = eqangle3 a d b c b d; e = reflect e a b c; f = reflect f a c d; k = on_line k a e, on_line k b d; l = on_line l a f, on_line l b d; o1 = circle o1 b e k; o2 = circle o2 d f l; x = on_line x o1 o2, on_circum x b e k ? cyclic x d f l

name: 2020 IMO Shortlist G5
problem:
Let $ABCD$ be a cyclic quadrilateral. Points $K, L, M, N$ are chosen on $AB, BC, CD, DA$ such that $KLMN$ is a rhombus with $KL \parallel AC$ and $LM \parallel BD$. Let $\omega_A, \omega_B, \omega_C, \omega_D$ be the incircles of $\triangle ANK, \triangle BKL, \triangle CLM, \triangle DMN$.

Prove that the common internal tangents to $\omega_A$, and $\omega_C$ and the common internal tangents to $\omega_B$ and $\omega_D$ are concurrent.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; d = on_circum d a b c; k = on_line k a b; l = on_line l b c, on_pline l k a c; m = on_line m c d, on_pline m l b d; n = on_line n d a, on_pline n m k l; ta1 ta2 ta3 wa = incenter2 ta1 ta2 ta3 wa a n k; tb1 tb2 tb3 wb = incenter2 tb1 tb2 tb3 wb b k l; tc1 tc2 tc3 wc = incenter2 tc1 tc2 tc3 wc c l m; td1 td2 td3 wd = incenter2 td1 td2 td3 wd d m n; xa ya = cc_tangent0 xa ya wa ta1 wc tc1; xb yb = cc_tangent0 xb yb wb tb1 wd td1 ? coll xa xb yb

name: 2020 IMO Shortlist G6
problem: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with $AB < AC$, incenter $I$, and $A$ excenter $I_{A},$. The incircle meets $BC$ at $D$. Define $E = AD\cap BI_{A},$, $F = AD\cap CI_{A},$. Show that the circumcircle of $\triangle AID$ and $\triangle I_{A},EF$ are tangent to each other
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; i = incenter i a b c; iA = excenter iA a b c; d = foot d i b c; e = on_line e a d, on_line e b iA; f = on_line f a d, on_line f c iA; o1 = circle o1 iA e f; o2 = circle o2 a i d; z = on_line z o1 o2, on_circum z iA e f ? cyclic z a i d

name: 2020 IMO Shortlist G7
problem:
Let $P$ be a point on the circumcircle of acute triangle $ABC$. Let $D,E,F$ be the reflections of $P$ in the $A$-midline, $B$-midline, and $C$-midline. Let $\omega$ be the circumcircle of the triangle formed by the perpendicular bisectors of $AD, BE, CF$. 

Show that the circumcircles of $\triangle ADP, \triangle BEP, \triangle CFP,$ and $\omega$ share a common point.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; p = on_circum p a b c; m_a = midpoint m_a b c; m_b = midpoint m_b c a; m_c = midpoint m_c a b; d = reflect d p a m_a; e = reflect e p b m_b; f = reflect f p c m_c; g = on_bline g a d, on_bline g b e; h = on_bline h b e, on_bline h c f; i = on_bline i a d, on_bline i c f ? cyclic p g h i

name: 2020 IMO Shortlist G8
problem:
Let $ABC$ be a triangle with incenter $I$ and circumcircle $\Gamma$. Circles $\omega_{B},$ passing through $B$ and $\omega_{C},$ passing through $C$ are tangent at $I$. Let $\omega_{B},$ meet minor arc $AB$ of $\Gamma$ at $P$ and $AB$ at $M\neq B$, and let $\omega_{C},$ meet minor arc $AC$ of $\Gamma$ at $Q$ and $AC$ at $N\neq C$. Rays $PM$ and $QN$ meet at $X$. Let $Y$ be a point such that $YB$ is tangent to $\omega_{B},$ and $YC$ is tangent to $\omega_{C},$. 

Show that $A,X,Y$ are collinear.

Let $P$ be the intersection point of the lines $BD$ and $CH$. Let $\omega$ be the semicircle with diameter $BD$ that meets the segment $CB$ at an interior point. formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; h = foot h c a b; d = mirror d a h; p = on_line p b d, on_line p c h; q = on_dia q b d; r = on_line r c q, on_line r a d ? cyclic b d q r

name: 2015 IMO Shortlist G4
problem: Let $ABC$ be an acute triangle and let $M$ be the midpoint of $AC$. A circle $\omega$ passing through $B$ and $M$ meets the sides $AB$ and $BC$ at points $P$ and $Q$ respectively. Let $T$ be the point such that $BPTQ$ is a parallelogram. Suppose that $T$ lies on the circumcircle of $ABC$. Determine all possible values of $\frac{BT},{BM},$.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; m = midpoint m a c; p = on_line p a b; q = on_line q b c; t = on_circum t a b c, on_pline t p b q ? eqratio b t b m a c b c

name: 2015 IMO Shortlist G5
problem: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with $CA \neq CB$. Let $D$, $F$, and $G$ be the midpoints of the sides $AB$, $AC$, and $BC$ respectively. A circle $\Gamma$ passing through $C$ and tangent to $AB$ at $D$ meets the segments $AF$ and $BG$ at $H$ and $I$, respectively. The points $H'$ and $I'$ are symmetric to $H$ and $I$ about $F$ and $G$, respectively. The line $H'I'$ meets $CD$ and $FG$ at $Q$ and $M$, respectively. The line $CM$ meets $\Gamma$ again at $P$. Prove that $CQ = QP$.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; d = midpoint d a b; f = midpoint f a c; g = midpoint g b c; h = on_line h a f; i = on_line i b g; h' = mirror h' h f; i' = mirror i' i g; q = on_line q h' i', on_line q c d; m = on_line m h' i', on_line m f g; p = free p ? cong c q q p

name: 2015 IMO Shortlist G6
problem:
Let $ABC$ be an acute triangle with $AB > AC$. Let $\Gamma $ be its circumcircle, $H$ its orthocenter, and $F$ the foot of the altitude from $A$. Let $M$ be the midpoint of $BC$. Let $Q$ be the point on $\Gamma$ such that $\angle HQA = 90^{\circ},$ and let $K$ be the point on $\Gamma$ such that $\angle HKQ = 90^{\circ},$. Assume that the points $A$, $B$, $C$, $K$ and $Q$ are all different and lie on $\Gamma$ in this order.

Prove that the circumcircles of triangles $KQH$ and $FKM$ are tangent to each other.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; h = orthocenter h a b c; f = foot f a b c; m = midpoint m b c; q = on_circum q a b c, on_dia q h a; k = on_circum k a b c, on_dia k h q ? eqangle q k k h m k k f

name: 2015 IMO Shortlist G7
problem: Let $ABCD$ be a convex quadrilateral, and let $P$, $Q$, $R$, and $S$ be points on the sides $AB$, $BC$, $CD$, and $DA$, respectively. Let the line segment $PR$ and $QS$ meet at $O$. Suppose that each of the quadrilaterals $APOS$, $BQOP$, $CROQ$, and $DSOR$ has an incircle. Prove that the lines $AC$, $PQ$, and $RS$ are either concurrent or parallel to each other.
formal_statement: a = free a; b = free b; c = free c; d = free d; p = on_line p a b; q = on_line q b c; r = on_line r c d; s = on_line s d a; o = on_line o p r, on_line o q s ? para a c p q

name: 2015 IMO Shortlist G8
problem:
A [i]triangulation[/i] of a convex polygon $\Pi$ is a partitioning of $\Pi$ into triangles by diagonals having no common points other than the vertices of the polygon. We say that a triangulation is a [i]Thaiangulation[/i] if all triangles in it have the same area.

Prove that any two different Thaiangulations of a convex polygon $\Pi$ differ by exactly two triangles. (In other words, prove that it is possible to replace one pair of triangles in the first Thaiangulation with a different pair of triangles so as to obtain the second Thaiangulation.)
formal_statement: p1 p2 p3 = triangle p1 p2 p3; p4 = on_line p4 p1 p2 ? cong p1 p2 p3 p4

name: 2014 IMO Shortlist G1
problem: Let $P$ and $Q$ be on segment $BC$ of an acute triangle $ABC$ such that $\angle PAB=\angle BCA$ and $\angle CAQ=\angle ABC$. Let $M$ and $N$ be the points on $AP$ and $AQ$, respectively, such that $P$ is the midpoint of $AM$ and $Q$ is the midpoint of $AN$. Prove that the intersection of $BM$ and $CN$ is on the circumference of triangle $ABC$.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; p = on_line p b c, eqangle3 p a b b c a; q = on_line q b c, eqangle3 q a c a b c; m = mirror m a p; n = mirror n a q; r = on_line r b m, on_line r c n ? cyclic a b c r

name: 2014 IMO Shortlist G2
problem: Let $ABC$ be a triangle. The points $K, L,$ and $M$ lie on the segments $BC, CA,$ and $AB,$ respectively, such that the lines $AK, BL,$ and $CM$ intersect in a common point. Prove that it is possible to choose two of the triangles $ALM, BMK,$ and $CKL$ whose inradii sum up to at least the inradius of the triangle $ABC$.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; k = on_line k b c; l = on_line l c a; m = on_line m a b; i = incenter i a b c; i1 = incenter i1 a l m; i2 = incenter i2 b m k; i3 = incenter i3 c k l ? eqratio i i1 i2 i3 i i2 i i3

name: 2014 IMO Shortlist G3
problem:
Let $\Omega$ and $O$ be the circumcircle and the circumcentre of an acute-angled triangle $ABC$ with $AB > BC$. The angle bisector of $\angle ABC$ intersects $\Omega$ at $M \ne B$. Let $\Gamma$ be the circle with diameter $BM$. The angle bisectors of $\angle AOB$ and $\angle BOC$ intersect $\Gamma$ at points $P$ and $Q,$ respectively. The point $R$ is chosen on the line $P Q$ so that $BR = MR$. Prove that $BR\parallel AC$.
(Here we always assume that an angle bisector is a ray.)
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; o = circle o a b c; m = angle_bisector m a b c, on_circum m a b c; p = angle_bisector p a o b, on_dia p b m; q = angle_bisector q b o c, on_dia q b m; r = on_line r p q, on_bline r b m ? para b r a c

name: 2014 IMO Shortlist G4
problem: Consider a fixed circle $\Gamma$ with three fixed points $A, B,$ and $C$ on it. Also, let us fix a real number $\lambda \in(0,1)$. For a variable point $P \not\in\{A, B, C\},$ on $\Gamma$, let $M$ be the point on the segment $CP$ such that $CM =\lambda\cdot  CP$ . Let $Q$ be the second point of intersection of the circumcircles of the triangles $AMP$ and $BMC$. Prove that as $P$ varies, the point $Q$ lies on a fixed circle.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; o = circle o a b c; p = on_circum p a b c; m = on_line m c p; q = on_circum q a m p, on_circum q b m c ? cyclic a b c q

name: 2014 IMO Shortlist G5
problem:
Convex quadrilateral $ABCD$ has $\angle ABC = \angle CDA = 90^{\circ},$. Point $H$ is the foot of the perpendicular from $A$ to $BD$. Points $S$ and $T$ lie on sides $AB$ and $AD$, respectively, such that $H$ lies inside triangle $SCT$ and \[
\angle CHS - \angle CSB = 90^{\circ},, \quad \angle THC - \angle DTC = 90^{\circ},. \] Prove that line $BD$ is tangent to the circumcircle of triangle $TSH$.
formal_statement: a = free a; b = free b; c = free c; d = free d; h = foot h a b d; s = on_line s a b; t = on_line t a d ? eqangle b h h s h t t s

name: 2014 IMO Shortlist G6
problem:
Let $ABC$ be a fixed acute-angled triangle. Consider some points $E$ and $F$ lying on the sides $AC$ and $AB$, respectively, and let $M$ be the midpoint of $EF$ . Let the perpendicular bisector of $EF$ intersect the line $BC$ at $K$, and let the perpendicular bisector of $MK$ intersect the lines $AC$ and $AB$ at $S$ and $T$ , respectively. We call the pair $(E, F )$ $\textit{interesting},$, if the quadrilateral $KSAT$ is cyclic.
    Suppose that the pairs $(E_1 , F_1 )$ and $(E_2 , F_2 )$ are interesting. Prove that $\displaystyle\frac{E_1 E_2},{AB},=\frac{F_1 F_2},{AC},$
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; e1 = on_line e1 a c; f1 = on_line f1 a b; m1 = midpoint m1 e1 f1; k1 = on_bline k1 e1 f1, on_line k1 b c; s1 = on_bline s1 m1 k1, on_line s1 a c; t1 = on_bline t1 m1 k1, on_line t1 a b; e2 = on_line e2 a c; f2 = on_line f2 a b; m2 = midpoint m2 e2 f2; k2 = on_bline k2 e2 f2, on_line k2 b c; s2 = on_bline s2 m2 k2, on_line s2 a c; t2 = on_bline t2 m2 k2, on_line t2 a b ? eqratio e1 e2 a b f1 f2 a c

name: 2014 IMO Shortlist G7
problem: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with circumcircle $\Omega$ and incentre $I$. Let the line passing through $I$ and perpendicular to $CI$ intersect the segment $BC$ and the arc $BC$ (not containing $A$) of $\Omega$ at points $U$ and $V$ , respectively. Let the line passing through $U$ and parallel to $AI$ intersect $AV$ at $X$, and let the line passing through $V$ and parallel to $AI$ intersect $AB$ at $Y$ . Let $W$ and $Z$ be the midpoints of $AX$ and $BC$, respectively. Prove that if the points $I, X,$ and $Y$ are collinear, then the points $I, W ,$ and $Z$ are also collinear.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; i = incenter i a b c; u = on_line u b c, on_tline u i c i; v = on_circum v a b c, on_tline v i c i; x = on_pline x u a i, on_line x a v; y = on_pline y v a i, on_line y a b; w = midpoint w a x; z = midpoint z b c ? coll i w z

name: 2013 IMO Shortlist G1
problem: Let $ABC$ be an acute triangle with orthocenter $H$, and let $W$ be a point on the side $BC$, lying strictly between $B$ and $C$. The points $M$ and $N$ are the feet of the altitudes from $B$ and $C$, respectively. Analogously, denote by $\omega_2$ the circumcircle of triangle $CWM$, and let $Y$ be the point such that $WY$ is a diameter of $\omega_2$. Prove that $X,Y$ and $H$ are collinear.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; h = orthocenter h a b c; w = on_line w b c; m = foot m b a c; n = foot n c a b; p = circle p b w n; x = on_circle x p w, mirror x w p; q = circle q c w m; y = on_circle y q w, mirror y w q ? coll x y h

formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; m = midpoint m a b; n = midpoint n a c; t = on_circum t a b c, on_bline t b c; x = on_circum x a m t, on_bline x a c; y = on_circum y a n t, on_bline y a b; k = on_line k m n, on_line k x y ? cong k a k t

name: 2013 IMO Shortlist G3
problem: In a triangle $ABC$, let $D$ and $E$ be the feet of the angle bisectors of angles $A$ and $B$, respectively. A rhombus is inscribed into the quadrilateral $AEDB$ (all vertices of the rhombus lie on different sides of $AEDB$). Let $\varphi$ be the non-obtuse angle of the rhombus. Prove that $\varphi \le \max \{  \angle BAC, \angle ABC  \},$.

name: 2013 IMO Shortlist G4
problem: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with $\angle B > \angle C$. Suppose that there exists an interior point $D$ of segment $BQ$ for which $PD=PB$. Let the ray $AD$ intersect the circle $ABC$ at $R \neq A$. Prove that $QB = QR$.

name: 2013 IMO Shortlist G5
problem: Let $ABCDEF$ be a convex hexagon with $AB=DE$, $BC=EF$, $CD=FA$, and $\angle A-\angle D = \angle C -\angle F = \angle E -\angle B$. Prove that the diagonals $AD$, $BE$, and $CF$ are concurrent.
formal_statement: a b = segment a b; b c = segment b c; c d = segment c d; d e = segment d e; e f = segment e f; f a = segment f a; x = on_line x a d, on_line x b e ? coll x c f

name: 2013 IMO Shortlist G6
problem: Let the excircle of triangle $ABC$ opposite the vertex $A$ be tangent to the side $BC$ at the point $A_1$. Define the points $B_1$ on $CA$ and $C_1$ on $AB$ analogously, using the excircles opposite $B$ and $C$, respectively. Suppose that the circumcentre of triangle $A_1B_1C_1$ lies on the circumcircle of triangle $ABC$. Prove that triangle $ABC$ is right-angled.

name: 2012 IMO Shortlist G1
problem:
Given triangle $ABC$ the point $J$ is the centre of the excircle opposite the vertex $A.$ This excircle is tangent to the side $BC$ at $M$, and to the lines $AB$ and $AC$ at $K$ and $L$, respectively. The lines $LM$ and $BJ$ meet at $F$, and the lines $KM$ and $CJ$ meet at $G.$ Let $S$ be the point of intersection of the lines $AF$ and $BC$, and let $T$ be the point of intersection of the lines $AG$ and $BC.$ Prove that $M$ is the midpoint of $ST.$

(The [i]excircle[/i] of $ABC$ opposite the vertex $A$ is the circle that is tangent to the line segment $BC$, to the ray $AB$ beyond $B$, and to the ray $AC$ beyond $C$.)
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; j = excenter j a b c; m = foot m j b c; k = foot k j a b; l = foot l j a c; f = on_line f l m, on_line f b j; g = on_line g k m, on_line g c j; s = on_line s a f, on_line s b c; t = on_line t a g, on_line t b c ? cong s m m t

name: 2012 IMO Shortlist G2
problem: Let $ABCD$ be a cyclic quadrilateral whose diagonals $AC$ and $BD$ meet at $E$. The extensions of the sides $AD$ and $BC$ beyond $A$ and $B$ meet at $F$. Let $G$ be the point such that $ECGD$ is a parallelogram, and let $H$ be the image of $E$ under reflection in $AD$. Prove that $D,H,F,G$ are concyclic.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; d = on_circum d a b c; e = on_line e a c, on_line e b d; f = on_line f a d, on_line f b c; g = on_pline g c e d, on_pline g d e c; h = reflect h e a d ? cyclic d h f g

name: 2012 IMO Shortlist G3
problem: In an acute triangle $ABC$ the points $D,E$ and $F$ are the feet of the altitudes through $A,B$ and $C$ respectively. The incenters of the triangles $AEF$ and $BDF$ are $I_1$ and $I_2$ respectively; the circumcenters of the triangles $ACI_1$ and $BCI_2$ are $O_1$ and $O_2$ respectively. Prove that $I_1I_2$ and $O_1O_2$ are parallel.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; d = foot d a b c; e = foot e b c a; f = foot f c a b; i1 = incenter i1 a e f; i2 = incenter i2 b d f; o1 = circle o1 a c i1; o2 = circle o2 b c i2 ? para i1 i2 o1 o2

name: 2012 IMO Shortlist G4
problem: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with $AB \neq AC$ and circumcenter $O$. The bisector of $\angle BAC$ intersects $BC$ at $D$. Let $E$ be the reflection of $D$ with respect to the midpoint of $BC$. The lines through $D$ and $E$ perpendicular to $BC$ intersect the lines $AO$ and $AD$ at $X$ and $Y$ respectively. Prove that the quadrilateral $BXCY$ is cyclic.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; o = circle o a b c; d = angle_bisector d b a c, on_line d b c; m = midpoint m b c; e = mirror e d m; x = on_tline x d b c, on_line x a o; y = on_tline y e b c, on_line y a d ? cyclic b x c y

name: 2012 IMO Shortlist G5
problem:
Let $ABC$ be a triangle with $\angle BCA=90^{\circ},$, and let $D$ be the foot of the altitude from $C$. Let $X$ be a point in the interior of the segment $CD$. Let $K$ be the point on the segment $AX$ such that $BK=BC$. Similarly, let $L$ be the point on the segment $BX$ such that $AL=AC$. Let $M$ be the point of intersection of $AL$ and $BK$.

Show that $MK=ML$.
formal_statement: a b = segment a b; c = on_dia c b a; d = foot d c a b; x = on_line x c d; k = on_line k a x, eqdistance k b b c; l = on_line l b x, eqdistance l a a c; m = on_line m a l, on_line m b k ? cong m k m l

name: 2012 IMO Shortlist G6
problem: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with circumcenter $O$ and incenter $I$. The points $D,E$ and $F$ on the sides $BC,CA$ and $AB$ respectively are such that $BD+BF=CA$ and $CD+CE=AB$. The circumcircles of the triangles $BFD$ and $CDE$ intersect at $P \neq D$. Prove that $OP=OI$.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; o = circle o a b c; i = incenter i a b c; d = on_line d b c; e = on_line e c a; f = on_line f a b; p = on_circum p b f d, on_circum p c d e ? cong o p o i

name: 2012 IMO Shortlist G7
problem: Let $ABCD$ be a convex quadrilateral with non-parallel sides $BC$ and $AD$. Assume that there is a point $E$ on the side $BC$ such that the quadrilaterals $ABED$ and $AECD$ are circumscribed. Prove that there is a point $F$ on the side $AD$ such that the quadrilaterals $ABCF$ and $BCDF$ are circumscribed if and only if $AB$ is parallel to $CD$.
formal_statement: a b = segment a b; b c = segment b c; c d = segment c d; d a = segment d a; e = on_line e b c; f = on_line f a d ? para a b c d

name: 2012 IMO Shortlist G8
problem: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with circumcircle $\omega$ and $\ell$ a line without common points with $\omega$. Denote by $P$ the foot of the perpendicular from the center of $\omega$ to $\ell$. The side-lines $BC,CA,AB$ intersect $\ell$ at the points $X,Y,Z$ different from $P$. Prove that the circumcircles of the triangles $AXP$, $BYP$ and $CZP$ have a common point different from $P$ or are mutually tangent at $P$.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; o = circle o a b c; l1 = free l1; l2 = free l2; p = foot p o l1 l2; x = on_line x b c, on_line x l1 l2; y = on_line y c a, on_line y l1 l2; z = on_line z a b, on_line z l1 l2 ? cyc a x p b

name: 2011 IMO Shortlist G1
problem: Let $ABC$ be an acute triangle. Let $\omega$ be a circle whose centre $L$ lies on the side $BC$. Suppose that $\omega$ is tangent to $AB$ at $B'$ and $AC$ at $C'$. Suppose also that the circumcentre $O$ of triangle $ABC$ lies on the shorter arc $B'C'$ of $\omega$. Prove that the circumcircle of $ABC$ and $\omega$ meet at two points.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; l = on_line l b c; b' = on_line b' a b, on_circle b' l a; c' = on_line c' a c, on_circle c' l a; o = circle o a b c ? cyc a b b' c'

name: 2011 IMO Shortlist G2
problem:
Let $A_1A_2A_3A_4$ be a non-cyclic quadrilateral. Let $O_1$ and $r_1$ be the circumcentre and the circumradius of the triangle $A_2A_3A_4$. Define $O_2,O_3,O_4$ and $r_2,r_3,r_4$ in a similar way. Prove that
\[\frac{1},{O_1A_1^2-r_1^2},+\frac{1},{O_2A_2^2-r_2^2},+\frac{1},{O_3A_3^2-r_3^2},+\frac{1},{O_4A_4^2-r_4^2},=0.\]
formal_statement: a1 = free a1; a2 = free a2; a3 = free a3; a4 = free a4; o1 = circle o1 a2 a3 a4; o2 = circle o2 a3 a4 a1; o3 = circle o3 a4 a1 a2; o4 = circle o4 a1 a2 a3 ? eqratio a1 o1 a2 o1 a3 o1 a4 o1

name: 2011 IMO Shortlist G3
problem: Let $ABCD$ be a convex quadrilateral whose sides $AD$ and $BC$ are not parallel. Suppose that the circles with diameters $AB$ and $CD$ meet at points $E$ and $F$ inside the quadrilateral. Let $\omega_E$ be the circle through the feet of the perpendiculars from $E$ to the lines $AB,BC$ and $CD$. Let $\omega_F$ be the circle through  the feet of the perpendiculars from $F$ to the lines $CD,DA$ and $AB$. Prove that the midpoint of the segment $EF$ lies on the line through the two intersections of $\omega_E$ and $\omega_F$.
formal_statement: a b = segment a b; b c = segment b c; c d = segment c d; d a = segment d a; e = on_dia e a b, on_dia e c d; f = on_dia f a b, on_dia f c d; xe1 = foot xe1 e a b; xe2 = foot xe2 e b c; xe3 = foot xe3 e c d; xf1 = foot xf1 f c d; xf2 = foot xf2 f d a; xf3 = foot xf3 f a b; u = on_circum u xe1 xe2 xe3, on_circum u xf1 xf2 xf3; v = on_circum v xe1 xe2 xe3, on_circum v xf1 xf2 xf3; m = midpoint m e f ? coll m u v

name: 2011 IMO Shortlist G4
problem: Let $ABC$ be an acute triangle with circumcircle $\Omega$. Let $B_0$ be the midpoint of $AC$ and let $C_0$ be the midpoint of $AB$. Let $D$ be the foot of the altitude from $A$ and let $G$ be the centroid of the triangle $ABC$. Let $\omega$ be a circle through $B_0$ and $C_0$ that is tangent to the circle $\Omega$ at a point $X\not= A$. Prove that the points $D,G$ and $X$ are collinear.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; b0 = midpoint b0 a c; c0 = midpoint c0 a b; d = foot d a b c; g = on_line g b0 b, on_line g c0 c; x = on_circum x a b c ? coll d g x

name: 2011 IMO Shortlist G5
problem: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with incentre $I$ and circumcircle $\omega$. Let $D$ and $E$ be the second intersection points of $\omega$ with $AI$ and $BI$, respectively. The chord $DE$ meets $AC$ at a point $F$, and $BC$ at a point $G$. Let $P$ be the intersection point of the line through $F$ parallel to $AD$ and the line through $G$ parallel to $BE$. Suppose that the tangents to $\omega$ at $A$ and $B$ meet at a point $K$. Prove that the three lines $AE,BD$ and $KP$ are either parallel or concurrent.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; i = incenter i a b c; d = on_line d a i, on_circum d a b c; e = on_line e b i, on_circum e a b c; f = on_line f d e, on_line f a c; g = on_line g d e, on_line g b c; p = on_pline p f a d, on_pline p g b e; k = free k ? eqangle a e e b k p p b

name: 2011 IMO Shortlist G6
problem: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with $AB=AC$ and let $D$ be the midpoint of $AC$. The angle bisector of $\angle BAC$ intersects the circle through $D,B$  and $C$ at the point $E$  inside the triangle $ABC$. The line $BD$ intersects the circle through $A,E$ and $B$ in two points $B$ and $F$. The lines $AF$ and $BE$ meet at a point $I$, and the lines $CI$ and $BD$ meet at a point $K$. Show that $I$ is the incentre of triangle $KAB$.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; d = midpoint d a c; e = angle_bisector e b a c, on_circum e d b c; f = on_line f b d, on_circum f a e b; i = on_line i a f, on_line i b e; k = on_line k c i, on_line k b d ? eqangle k a i k b i

name: 2011 IMO Shortlist G7

name: 2011 IMO Shortlist G8
problem: Let $ABC$ be an acute triangle with circumcircle $\Gamma$. name: 2010 IMO Shortlist G1

name: 2010 IMO Shortlist G2
problem: Let $P$ be a point interior to triangle $ABC$ (with $CA \neq CB$). The lines $AP$, $BP$ and $CP$ meet again its circumcircle $\Gamma$ at $K$, $L$, respectively $M$. The tangent line at $C$ to $\Gamma$ meets the line $AB$ at $S$. Show that from $SC = SP$ follows $MK = ML$.

name: 2010 IMO Shortlist G3
problem:
Let $A_1A_2 \ldots A_n$ be a convex polygon. Point $P$ inside this polygon is chosen so that its projections $P_1, \ldots , P_n$ onto lines $A_1A_2, \ldots , A_nA_1$ respectively lie on the sides of the polygon. Prove that for arbitrary points $X_1, \ldots , X_n$ on sides $A_1A_2, \ldots , A_nA_1$ respectively,
\[\max \left\{ \frac{X_1X_2},{P_1P_2},, \ldots, \frac{X_nX_1},{P_nP_1}, \right\}, \geq 1.\]

name: 2010 IMO Shortlist G5

name: 2010 IMO Shortlist G7
problem: Three circular arcs $\gamma_1, \gamma_2,$ and $\gamma_3$ connect the points $A$ and $C.$ These arcs lie in the same half-plane defined by line $AC$ in such a way that arc $\gamma_2$ lies between the arcs $\gamma_1$ and $\gamma_3.$ Point $B$ lies on the segment $AC.$ Let $h_1, h_2$, and $h_3$ be three rays starting at $B,$ lying in the same half-plane, $h_2$ being between $h_1$ and $h_3.$ For $i, j = 1, 2, 3,$ denote by $V_{ij},$ the point of intersection of $h_i$ and $\gamma_j$ (see the Figure below). Denote by $\widehat{V_{ij},V_{kj},},\widehat{V_{kl},V_{il},},$ the curved quadrilateral, whose sides are the segments $V_{ij},V_{il},,$ $V_{kj},V_{kl},$ and arcs $V_{ij},V_{kj},$ and $V_{il},V_{kl},.$ We say that this quadrilateral is $circumscribed$ if there exists a circle touching these two segments and two arcs. Prove that if the curved quadrilaterals $\widehat{V_{11},V_{21},},\widehat{V_{22},V_{12},},, \widehat{V_{12},V_{22},},\widehat{V_{23},V_{13},},,\widehat{V_{21},V_{31},},\widehat{V_{32},V_{22},},$ are circumscribed, then the curved quadrilateral $\widehat{V_{22},V_{32},},\widehat{V_{33},V_{23},},$ is circumscribed, too.
formal_statement: a c = segment a c; b = on_line b a c; h1 = free h1; h2 = free h2; h3 = free h3; v11 = free v11; v12 = free v12; v13 = free v13; v21 = free v21; v22 = free v22; v23 = free v23; v31 = free v31; v32 = free v32; v33 = free v33 ? cyclic v22 v32 v33 v23

name: 2009 IMO Shortlist G1

name: 2008 IMO Shortlist G1
problem:
Let $ H$ be the orthocenter of an acute-angled triangle $ ABC$. The circle $ \Gamma_{A},$ centered at the midpoint of $ BC$ and passing through $ H$ intersects the sideline $ BC$ at points  $ A_{1},$ and $ A_{2},$. Similarly, define the points $ B_{1},$, $ B_{2},$, $ C_{1},$ and $ C_{2},$.

formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; h = orthocenter h a b c; ma = midpoint ma b c; a1 = on_line a1 b c, on_circle a1 ma h; a2 = on_line a2 b c, on_circle a2 ma h; mb = midpoint mb a c; b1 = on_line b1 a c, on_circle b1 mb h; b2 = on_line b2 a c, on_circle b2 mb h; mc = midpoint mc a b; c1 = on_line c1 a b, on_circle c1 mc h; c2 = on_line c2 a b, on_circle c2 mc h ? cyclic a1 a2 b1 b2 c1 c2

name: 2008 IMO Shortlist G2
