formal_statement: a = free a; b = free b; c = free c; d = free d; o = free o; a1 = foot a1 o a b; b1 = foot b1 o b c; c1 = foot c1 o c d; d1 = foot d1 o d a; a2 = foot a2 o a1 b1; b2 = foot b2 o b1 c1; c2 = foot c2 o c1 d1; d2 = foot d2 o d1 a1; a3 = foot a3 o a2 b2; b3 = foot b3 o b2 c2; c3 = foot c3 o c2 d2; d3 = foot d3 o d2 a2; a4 = foot a4 o a3 b3; b4 = foot b4 o b3 c3; c4 = foot c4 o c3 d3; d4 = foot d4 o d3 a3 ? eqangle a b b c a4 b4 b4 c4

name: 1977 IMO Shortlist T12
problem: In the interior of a square $ABCD$ we construct the equilateral triangles $ABK, BCL, CDM, DAN.$ Prove that the midpoints of the four segments $KL, LM, MN, NK$ and the midpoints of the eight segments $AK, BK, BL, CL, CM, DM, DN, AN$ are the 12 vertices of a regular dodecagon.
formal_statement: a b = segment a b; b c = segment b c; c d = segment c d; d a = segment d a; k = on_circle k a b, on_circle k b a; l = on_circle l b c, on_circle l c b; m = on_circle m c d, on_circle m d c; n = on_circle n d a, on_circle n a d; xkl = midpoint xkl k l; xlm = midpoint xlm l m; xmn = midpoint xmn m n; xnk = midpoint xnk n k; xak = midpoint xak a k; xbk = midpoint xbk b k; xbl = midpoint xbl b l; xcl = midpoint xcl c l; xcm = midpoint xcm c m; xdm = midpoint xdm d m; xdn = midpoint xdn d n; xan = midpoint xan a n ? eqratio xkl xlm xlm xmn xmn xnk xnk xkl

name: 1976 IMO Shortlist T1
problem: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with bisectors $AA_1,BB_1, CC_1$ ($A_1 \in  BC$, etc.) and $M$ their common point. Consider the triangles $MB_1A, MC_1A,MC_1B,MA_1B,MA_1C,MB_1C$, and their inscribed circles. Prove that if four of these six inscribed circles have equal radii, then $AB = BC = CA.$
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; a1 = angle_bisector a1 b a c, on_line a1 b c; b1 = angle_bisector b1 c b a, on_line b1 c a; c1 = angle_bisector c1 a c b, on_line c1 a b; m = incenter m a b c ? eqratio a b b c b c c a

name: 1976 IMO Shortlist T3
problem: In a convex quadrilateral (in the plane) with the area of $32 \text{ cm},^{2},$ the sum of two opposite sides and a diagonal is $16 \text{ cm},$. Determine all the possible values that the other diagonal can have.
formal_statement: a = free a; b = free b; c = free c; d = free d; e = free e; f = free f; g = free g; h = free h ? eqratio a b c d e f g h

name: 1975 IMO Shortlist T8
problem:
In the plane of a triangle $ABC,$ in its exterior$,$ we draw the triangles $ABR, BCP, CAQ$ so that $\angle PBC = \angle CAQ = 45^{\circ},$, $\angle BCP = \angle QCA = 30^{\circ},$, $\angle ABR = \angle RAB = 15^{\circ},$.

Prove that 

[b]a.)[/b] $\angle QRP = 90\,^{\circ},,$ and 

[b]b.)[/b] $QR = RP.$
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; r = free r; p = free p; q = free q ? perp q r r p, cong q r r p

name: 1975 IMO Shortlist T13
problem:
Let $A_0,A_1, \ldots , A_n$ be points in a plane such that
(i)	$A_0A_1 \leq \frac{1},{ 2}, A_1A_2  \leq  \cdots  \leq  \frac{1},{2^{n-1}, }, A_{n-1},A_n$ and
(ii) $0 < \measuredangle A_0A_1A_2 < \measuredangle A_1A_2A_3 < \cdots < \measuredangle A_{n-2},A_{n-1},A_n < 180^\circ,$
where all these angles have the same orientation. Prove that the segments $A_kA_{k+1},,A_mA_{m+1},$ do not intersect for each $k$ and $n$ such that $0 \leq k \leq m - 2 < n- 2.$
formal_statement: a0 = free a0; a1 = free a1; a2 = free a2; a3 = free a3; a4 = free a4 ? eqratio a0 a1 a1 a2 a2 a3 a3 a4

name: 1974 IMO Shortlist T5
problem: Let $A_r,B_r, C_r$ be points on the circumference of a given circle $S$. From the triangle $A_rB_rC_r$, called $\Delta_r$, the triangle $\Delta_{r+1},$ is obtained by constructing the points $A_{r+1},,B_{r+1},, C_{r+1}, $on $S$ such that $A_{r+1},A_r$ is parallel to $B_rC_r$, $B_{r+1},B_r$ is parallel to $C_rA_r$, and $C_{r+1},C_r$ is parallel to $A_rB_r$. Each angle of $\Delta_1$ is an integer number of degrees and those integers are not multiples of $45$. Prove that at least two of the triangles $\Delta_1,\Delta_2, \ldots ,\Delta_{15},$  are congruent.
formal_statement: a1 b1 c1 = triangle a1 b1 c1; s = circle s a1 b1 c1; a2 = on_pline a2 a1 b1 c1, on_circle a2 s a1; b2 = on_pline b2 b1 c1 a1, on_circle b2 s b1; c2 = on_pline c2 c1 a1 b1, on_circle c2 s c1 ? cong a1 b1 a2 b2

name: 1974 IMO Shortlist T10
problem: Let $ABC$ be a triangle. Prove that there exists a point $D$ on the side $AB$ of the triangle $ABC$, such that $CD$ is the geometric mean of $AD$ and $DB$, iff the triangle $ABC$ satisfies the inequality $\sin A\sin B\le\sin^2\frac{C},{2},$.
formal_statement: a b c = triangle a b c; d = on_line d a b ? eqratio c d a d d b c d
